moves.1. e4: An uncommon opening lead to a blunder that sealed the fate of the game
moves.1... e5 2. Bb5: Portuguese opening, my frequent choice against e5
moves.4... Bxe5:
or:
a) Ng4 Qxg4
b) Bb4 c3 and black has two pieces en prise, will lose one of them
moves.5. f4: to support e5, if Bxf4 then Bxf4 and white's activity is overwhelming
moves.5... Nxe4: wins another pawn, but then I have Qd5 leaving again two black pieces "en prise"
moves.6. Qd5: again attacking both black pieces and also f7
moves.8. Nf3: again two of black pieces attacked
moves.8... Qh5: the knight is defended by my queen, and e2 is defended by my b5 bishop
moves.9. Ng5: a mate threat has appeared now, and black still has two pieces "en prise"
moves.9... Bf6 10. hxg3: to get some pieces back and harden black's queen life
moves.11. Qe4+:
black king moves, or the bishop blocks the check and then Rxh5 win the queen, plus with my rook on h5 and knight on g5 I can avoid the pin that wins back the queen:
 
11...Kd8 12.Rxh5:

a) 12...Re8 to pin the queen 13.Nxf7 wins the rook also
b) 12...Bxg5 I don't even have to move the queen away, 13.Rxg5 and I have my rook to block black's rook 13...Re8 14.Re5
moves.11... Be7 12. Rxh5: now if cxb5, I'll play Nxh7 aimed at Nf6+ to win the h8 rook
